_decoded_content.title: Don't show button to open Log Modal on Pipelines page if pipeline has never run
Use plugin name in UI when label is not set
Connection Setup UI fails when plugin docs URL is not set
Clarify that only known plugins are displayed in the UI, and how known plugins can be added and made UI-ready
Clarify that pipelines UI only supports target-postgres
Restore "Custom" data source option in UI
Restore supported data sources in UI
Make it easier to run Meltano UI in Docker with Airflow and Postgres containers
If start_date is in the past, scheduled Airflow DAG runs immediately after initial manual pipeline run
_decoded_content.description:
The DAG's start_date is set to the extractor's start date, while it should just be set to the timestamp of pipeline creation, so that the first schedule run won't come until the next day (or hour, etc).

Right now though, the pipeline's start_date is used in the UI where really the extractor's start_date should be used.

_decoded_content.title: Pipeline may get stuck in "running" mode when Meltano is upgraded and/or restarted during run
_decoded_content.description:
On a user's MeltanoData.com instance, we saw a pipeline job that had (according to the "Run Log" modal "Elapsed" time) been running for more than 4 days. 

The log showed "The log is too large to display inline. Download it below.", but the "Download Log" button was disabled because (according to Meltano) the job hadn't finished running yet, so there was no way to see from the UI whether the job was actually still running and generating output, or not.

There is also not a way to cancel or otherwise delete a pipeline that has gotten stuck, so I ended up SSH'ing in and making the change myself. This is related to https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/issues/1493.

_decoded_content.title: Cancel running pipeline that was just created
_decoded_content.description:
### Opportunity Assessment


#### Summary

A user request of "It would be nice to be able to stop a running pipeline if it is a mistake".

**1. Exactly what problem will this solve? (value proposition)**

It is possible the pipeline that needs to be canceled is eating up a lot of resources, and loading a lot of data that won't be needed. Because we currently don't support removing data that has been loaded, it could create a messy Meltano account.

**2. For whom do we solve that problem? (target market)**

existing Meltano users

**3. How big is the opportunity? (market size)**

as a large as user base (not relevant if you haven't yet adopted)

**4. What alternatives are out there? (competitive landscape)**

n/a

**5. Why are we best suited to pursue this? (our differentiator)**



**6. Why now? (market window)**

No clear reason to act right now (moving to ~"Accepting Merge Requests" in the backlog)

**7. How will we get this product to market? (go-to-market strategy)**

small feature improvement, CHANGELOG and release notes

**8. How will we measure success/make money from this product? (metrics/revenue strategy)**

n/a, this is a feature

**9. What factors are critical to success? (solution requirements)**



**10. Given the above, what’s the recommendation? (go or no-go)**

Backlog

_decoded_content.title: Use a single port for serving the web app
_decoded_content.description:
### Problem

It's common for the built-in server in [Flask](https://flask.palletsprojects.com/en/1.1.x/quickstart/#quickstart) to use port `5000`. It's also common to use port `8080` to serve a web app.

However, documentation, tutorials, CLI output, and more reference the web app running on port `5000` or `8080`. This can cause some confusion on which port to expect for accessing the web app. This gets even more confusing when the web app is served on both ports locally when running `meltano ui` and in some cases the app is not even fully working, see https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/issues/1291.

### Proposal

Let's remove this confusion by doing the following:
1. Always reference web app access through the `8080` port.
2. Remove the web app from being served on the `5000` port.

### Risk

This affects both app configuration and documentation.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description:
As a start, I think it would be good to prioritize based on:
- urgency of getting feedback
- relative implementation difficulty
- symbiotic relationships between issues

_decoded_content.title: Reduce payloads with better code splitting for the web app
_decoded_content.description:
### Problem

The current payloads of the web app carry a lot of unused code including CSS and JavaScript to the client.

For example, **only 365 KB of 1.4 MB (26%) is being used** when loading the first page (`/pipeline/extract/`). More specifically, 69.8% of the JavaScript loaded on the first page is **not used**.

| Web app code coverage |
| ------ |
| ![Screenshot_2019-11-04_at_17.01.38](/uploads/6c628974ea0dc516434fb6191ae24f3c/Screenshot_2019-11-04_at_17.01.38.png) |

In addition, building the `metlano` package is already returning the following warnings:

```sh
 warning  

asset size limit: The following asset(s) exceed the recommended size limit (244 KiB).
This can impact web performance.
Assets: 
  static/css/app.75c71e1e.css (297 KiB)
  static/js/chunk-vendors.63e18de4.js (926 KiB)
  static/logos/marketo-logo.svg (961 KiB)

 warning  

entrypoint size limit: The following entrypoint(s) combined asset size exceeds the recommended limit (244 KiB). This can impact web performance.
Entrypoints:
  app (1.38 MiB)
      static/js/chunk-vendors.63e18de4.js
      static/css/app.75c71e1e.css
      static/js/app.2eb8093b.js

```

These warnings also pop-up when going through the [prerequisites](https://meltano.com/docs/contributing.html#prerequisites) section of the contribution guidelines.

### Proposal

1. In the long run, making better utilization of code splitting sounds great.
2. Since this could require a lot of effort, suppressing these warnings could be a simple step forward.

_decoded_content.title: Provide an intuitive way to manage anonymous usage data collection
_decoded_content.description:
### Background

Currently, [anonymous usage data](https://meltano.com/docs/environment-variables.html#anonymous-usage-data) collection is enabled by default for new projects unless explicitly disabled, for new, existing, or all projects, using the `--no_usage_stats` flag during project creation from the CLI, b) the `send_anonymous_usage_stats` setting in the `meltano.yml` file, or c) the `MELTANO_DISABLE_TRACKING` environment variable as described in the documentation.

### Problem

This makes it harder for someone to disable anonymous usage data for new, existing, or all projects which can have a negative impact on the product since usage data collection is closely related to privacy issues.

### Proposal

Let's make it easier to disable or enable anonymous usage data collection through the user interface.
1. This could include showing a toast message the first time you load the project mentioning usage data collection and provide an action button to disable usage data collection which is currently enabled by default.
2. In addition, providing a preference option in user profile settings could help make this more clear to the user.

### Benefits

Providing an option to disable usage data collection can have a positive impact on the product and new users since usage data collection is closely related to privacy issues.

### Design

TBD

### Risk

The current [focus](https://meltano.com/docs/roadmap.html#focus) of the team is to grow [Monthly Active UI Users (MAUI)](https://meltano.com/docs/roadmap.html#metrics) based on the anonymous usage data which is [enabled by default](https://meltano.com/docs/environment-variables.html#anonymous-usage-data).

_decoded_content.title: Improve header iconography, color, and layout
_decoded_content.description:
### Problem

Currently, the header has a) limited accessibility in terms of color contrast, b) makes it hard to distinguish active menu items, and more.

### Proposal

Use better color contrast, iconography, and structure to improve accessibility and usability. The following example uses some of the custom SVG icons from the [design system](https://design.gitlab.com) behind GitLab, see [`gitlab-svgs`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-svgs).

| Before | After |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![header-before](/uploads/cbe31dbe89153a680d6b3bd8014047e3/header-before.png) | ![header-after](/uploads/e447a2637e3bf0cc4650a271c2646e8e/header-after.png) |

_decoded_content.title: Introduce a loading spinner and replace progress bar where applicable
_decoded_content.description:
### Problem

Currently, the progress bar is used interchangeably for indicating loading status for all types of interactions including a) progress of a particular process and b) retrieval of data or performing slow computations.

| Do | Don't |
| ------ | ------ |
| Use progress bar for indicating progress of a particular process (more than X seconds). | Use a progress bar for indicating retrieving of data or performing slow computations (less than X seconds). |

### Proposal

Let's introduce a loading spinner and replace progress bar where applicable. For example, here's how loading extractor would look like using the [spinner](https://design.gitlab.com/components/spinner) component from `design.gitlab.com`.

| Before | After |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![Screenshot_2019-09-25_at_13.28.58](/uploads/6a6f98409fcb4e7156bd38f3bb5f851d/Screenshot_2019-09-25_at_13.28.58.png) | ![Screenshot_2019-09-25_at_13.28.48](/uploads/99d6361df8a8b867cd65ae83a087350e/Screenshot_2019-09-25_at_13.28.48.png) |

_decoded_content.title: Change casing to sentence case for titles, headings, labels, menu items, and buttons
_decoded_content.description:
### Problem

Maybe the intention _is_ to use title case everywhere but it looks unnecessary.

### Proposal

Since this is already using some buttons from the [Pajamas Design System](https://design.gitlab.com/) why not also adopt some of the [punctuation guidelines](https://design.gitlab.com/content/punctuation), too?

> Use sentence case for titles, headings, labels, menu items, and buttons. Use title case when referring to features or products. Note that some features are also objects.

This means that button labels should change from _Account Settings_ to _Account settings_, Edit Selections to _Edit selections_, etc. In contrast, step marker details can remain as is (e.g. _Source Connectors_, _Source Selections_, etc.)
